Authors: Treier K., Kabral N., Frey J.
Title: Trends in precipitation of air pollutants at Estonian monitoring stations 1994-2005
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Tartu, 46 Vanemuise St., 51014 Tartu, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Treier, K., Department of Geography, University of Tartu, 46 Vanemuise St., 51014 Tartu, Estonia; Kabral, N., Department of Geography, University of Tartu, 46 Vanemuise St., 51014 Tartu, Estonia; Frey, J., Department of Geography, University of Tartu, 46 Vanemuise St., 51014 Tartu, Estonia
Abstract: This study concentrates mainly on the 12-year time trends of annual average ion concentrations in bulk precipitation from 10 Estonian monitoring stations. Trends revealed by the nonparametric Mann-Kendall test mostly show a statistically significant decline and, according to the order of ion decline per year, three groups of stations could be differentiated: stations directly affected by an industrial region, NE industrial region background stations and natural background stations. Under different international requirements Estonia has undertaken serious obligations to reduce emissions of air pollutants. Total SO2 emissions from power plants in Estonia have fallen from about 60%, and emission of solid particles decreased twenty times during the period of 1990-2005. The highest decline of Ca concentrations occurred during the first three-year monitoring period of 1994-1996, and a high decline of SO 4-S in 1997-1999 and 2003-2005. © 2008 Estonian Academy Publishers.
Index Keywords: Bulk precipitation; Ion concentrations; Mann-Kendall test; Monitoring periods; Monitoring stations; Natural backgrounds; Non-parametric; Solid particles; Sulfur dioxide; Air pollution

Authors: Tsoutsos T.D.
Title: Barriers and benefits of Hydrogen-based autonomous power systems
Authors with affiliations: Tsoutsos, T.D.
Abstract: Hydrogen-based autonomous power systems (H-APS), comprising the focus of this book, offer a potential combination of performance and flexibility that is creating interest among end users. Current trends in the developed counties clearly favor a sustainable micropower, particularly from the standpoint of increased energy efficiency and reduced emissions. Meeting the increasingly competitive challenges of the market will require harnessing the full resource capability of available and emerging technologies with characteristics of high efficiency, reasonable cost, extreme reliability and minimised environmental impact.

Authors: Tsuda S., Kosaka H., Aizawa T.
Title: A study on effect of heterogeneity of oxygen concentration and temperature distributions in a combustion chamber on combustion and emissions of diesel engine
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Modeling and Diagnostics for Advanced Engine Systems, COMODIA 2008
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku Tokyo 152-8552, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsuda, S., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Kosaka, H., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Aizawa, T., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku Tokyo 152-8552, Japan
Abstract: Exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) is widely used for reduction of NOx emission from diesel engines. However, particulate matter emission and thermal efficiency tend to be worse at the high EGR ratios. EGR induces the heterogeneous distributions of oxygen and temperature in a combustion chamber and these heterogeneities affect the emissions and combustion characteristics of diesel engine. If the heterogeneities of oxygen and temperature distributions can be controlled, it is expected that the simultaneous reduction of NOx and PM from diesel engine will be achieved by active control of internal and external EGR devices. In this study, the NOx and PM emissions and combustion characteristics of diesel combustion achieved in various distributions of oxygen concentration and temperature are investigated in order to clarify the effect of these heterogeneities of surroundings on the diesel combustion. The experiment was conducted with the rapid compression expansion machine (RCEM) and the combustion chamber in which various distributions of intake gas can be formed. The enthalpy and the amount of oxygen entrained into the spray upstream the ignition region are selected as the parameters in order to clarify the effect of heterogeneities of surrounding conditions on the diesel spray combustion. The results indicated that the NOx and soot emissions from diesel combustion are governed mainly by the amount of enthalpy entrained into the spray upstream the ignition region, when the temperature distribution in a chamber is changed with keeping the oxygen fraction at constant. Copyright © 2008 by the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers.
Author Keywords: Diesel combustion; Heterogeneity; NOx; Soot; Temperature distribution
Index Keywords: Diesel combustion; Emissions and combustion; Exhaust gas recirculation (EGR); Heterogeneity; Heterogeneous distributions; NOx; Particulate matter emissions; Rapid compression expansion machines; Combustion chambers; Engines; Enthalpy; Exhaust gases; Ignition; Nitrogen oxides; Oxygen; Soot; Temperature distribution; Diesel engines

Authors: Tuba Z., Kaligarič M.
Title: Grassland ecology in changing climate and land use
Affiliations: Institute of Botany and Ecophysiology, Szent István University, Páter K. u. 1, Gödöllo, H-2103, Hungary; Plant Ecological Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Szent István University, Páter K. u. 1, Gödöllo, H-2103, Hungary; Biology Department, Faculty of Natural Sciences and Mathematics, University of Maribor, Koroška 160, SI-2000 Maribor, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Tuba, Z., Institute of Botany and Ecophysiology, Szent István University, Páter K. u. 1, Gödöllo, H-2103, Hungary, Plant Ecological Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Szent István University, Páter K. u. 1, Gödöllo, H-2103, Hungary; Kaligarič, M., Biology Department, Faculty of Natural Sciences and Mathematics, University of Maribor, Koroška 160, SI-2000 Maribor, Slovenia
Abstract: This brief overview decribes some structural and functional (including carbon cycling) aspects of grassland ecosystems, in particular with regard to the effects of global climate change and changes in land use. Afterward the papers briefly introduce the papers devoted to the above mentioned topics, which were selected for this special volume. As we can see, authors studied different kinds of management (including abandonment) and different parameters of climate change (CO 2, temperature, rainfall, etc.). They consider predominately vegetation parameters, including the various plant traits, carbon cycling, soil respiration and different ecophysiological traits in simulated climate change. Dealing with different impacts of climate and/or land-use changes on multi-species systems, that grassland communities certainly are, is exceeding merely experimental syn-thesized-community or single-species approach on one side and classical vegetation studies on the other. The complex responses of natural communities, including those under FACE systems, are not easy to interpret and understand. The importance of non-linear dynamics during climate changes is emphasized by Bartha et al. (2008). In these selected papers, grasslands appear to be a very dynamic and plastic ecosystem. Grasslands are highlighted from a new, much more topical point of view. Linking ecophysiology and vegetation science, which is characteristic for our selection of papers, is a promising tool to deal with problems on the ecosystem level in general, not only addressing the global climate change and land-use issues. © Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest.
Author Keywords: C and N cycling; Elevated air CO 2; Global climate change; Grassland communities; Land use; Salinity; Soil respiration

Authors: Turanjanin V., Bakic V., Jovanovic M., Pezo M.
Title: The energy benefits in the solar domestic hot water plant
Source title: CHISA 2008 - 18th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Sciences VINCA, Laboratory for Thermal Energy and Engineering, PO Box 522, 11001 Beograd, Serbia
Authors with affiliations: Turanjanin, V., Institute of Nuclear Sciences VINCA, Laboratory for Thermal Energy and Engineering, PO Box 522, 11001 Beograd, Serbia; Bakic, V., Institute of Nuclear Sciences VINCA, Laboratory for Thermal Energy and Engineering, PO Box 522, 11001 Beograd, Serbia; Jovanovic, M., Institute of Nuclear Sciences VINCA, Laboratory for Thermal Energy and Engineering, PO Box 522, 11001 Beograd, Serbia; Pezo, M., Institute of Nuclear Sciences VINCA, Laboratory for Thermal Energy and Engineering, PO Box 522, 11001 Beograd, Serbia
Abstract: The energy and environmental benefits of solar hot water production for domestic use are examined. A solar plant for hot-water production is investigated using the dynamic simulation code TSOL Expert. The hot-water demand temperature is controlled by a natural gas auxiliary heater. Annual energy performance, in terms of solar fraction, is calculated for the City of Belgrade. The solar system could substitute ≈ 62% of total hot water energy needs. It could also reduce combustion gases emissions, e.g., CO 2. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 18th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering (Prague, Czech Republic 8/24-28/2008).
Author Keywords: Energy benefit; Simulation; Solar domestic water heating; Solar fraction

Authors: Turetta A.P.D., Mendonca-Santos M.L., Anjos L.H.C., Berbara R.L.L.
Title: Spatial-temporal changes in land cover, soil properties and carbon stocks in Rio de Janeiro
Source title: Digital Soil Mapping with Limited Data
Affiliations: Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation - EMBRAPA Solos, Jardim Botânico, Rio de Janeiro, CEP 22460-000, RJ., Brazil; EMBRAPA Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation, National Center of Soil Research, CNPS, Rua Jardim Botânico, 1024. Jardim Botânico, Rio de Janeiro, RJ CEP 22460-000, Brazil; Universidade Federal Rural Do Rio de Janeiro, BR 465 Km47, Seropédica, RJ, CEP 23890-000, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Turetta, A.P.D., Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation - EMBRAPA Solos, Jardim Botânico, Rio de Janeiro, CEP 22460-000, RJ., Brazil; Mendonca-Santos, M.L., EMBRAPA Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation, National Center of Soil Research, CNPS, Rua Jardim Botânico, 1024. Jardim Botânico, Rio de Janeiro, RJ CEP 22460-000, Brazil; Anjos, L.H.C., Universidade Federal Rural Do Rio de Janeiro, BR 465 Km47, Seropédica, RJ, CEP 23890-000, Brazil; Berbara, R.L.L., Universidade Federal Rural Do Rio de Janeiro, BR 465 Km47, Seropédica, RJ, CEP 23890-000, Brazil
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate spatial-temporal dynamics of land cover of the Campo Grande and Santa Cruz Administration Regions, both in Rio de Janeiro city. LANDSAT5-TM images from 1984, 1994 and 1999 were used to create land cover maps. A Geographical Information System was used for integrating information into a cohesive and easy to consult cartographic base and database. Matrices were generated by applying Markov's Chains, which allow to describe, model and predict transitions of the land cover. This study examined the relationship between land use change, soil orders and carbon stock in the top 10 cm. It was possible to observe the land cover dynamics, with the conversion of agriculture, anthropogenic area and exposed soil in urban areas, especially in the period 1994 - 1999. Using secondary data, from soil survey reports, and combine it with the land cover maps in the temporal series, it was possible to observe a potentiality of this approach in soil properties-landscape modeling. The main finding of this study was that land use change is a dynamic process, and the use of soil properties based on secondary data - soil survey reports - can helps environmental planning, but the accuracy depends of the quality and the spatial data distribution. So, its stress that is important to planning the soils surveys for the good data exploitation for future projects. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media B.V.

Authors: Ugalde D., Van Vliet J., McGregor A., Slattery B.
Title: Policy options to manage greenhouse gas emissions from the livestock sector: An Australian perspective
Affiliations: Australian Greenhouse Office, Department of the Environment and Water, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Ugalde, D., Australian Greenhouse Office, Department of the Environment and Water, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia; Van Vliet, J., Australian Greenhouse Office, Department of the Environment and Water, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia; McGregor, A., Australian Greenhouse Office, Department of the Environment and Water, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia; Slattery, B., Australian Greenhouse Office, Department of the Environment and Water, GPO Box 787, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Abstract: The interface between policy and science provides rich opportunity to frame both the policy and science agendas for the reduction of emissions of greenhouse gases from agriculture. The current Greenhouse Gas in Animal Agriculture Conference (2007) provides a valuable forum for the development and integration of the two. Compared with the level of investments worldwide into technologies to reduce emissions from energy generation and transport, investments into managing and reducing emissions from the agriculture and land sectors have lagged, sadly, far behind. Nonetheless, there still remains strong opportunity to reduce substantially the net emissions from the land-based sector while also improving productivity and financial return (both short and long term). Over the past few decades, it has probably been the science agenda that provided the main impetus for understanding the management of processes that give rise to greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture and for improving management options to reduce these emissions. However, recently a range of new policy approaches (both in Australia and elsewhere) have come into play, and these approaches are now demanding a greater suite and possibly a different set of information from science - and over a short timeframe - to provide the technical means for change to be implemented. The challenge for science is to understand the new demands from the policy agendas, and to resolve how the science community can best deliver what is required. In this way science will be delivering additional benefits to agricultural industries and rural communities as activities in the land-based sector align with national interest and opportunities.
Index Keywords: agricultural emission; comparative study; emission control; environmental management; environmental policy; greenhouse gas; Australasia; Australia; Animalia

Authors: Uhýrek O., Hadač O., Kohout M., Schreiber I., Kubíček M.
Title: Nonlinear behaviour of reaction-transport systems of catalytic converters
Source title: CHISA 2008 - 18th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Department of Chemical Engineering, Center for Nonlinear Dynamics of Chemical and Biological Systems, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague 6, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Uhýrek, O., Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Department of Chemical Engineering, Center for Nonlinear Dynamics of Chemical and Biological Systems, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague 6, Czech Republic; Hadač, O., Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Department of Chemical Engineering, Center for Nonlinear Dynamics of Chemical and Biological Systems, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague 6, Czech Republic; Kohout, M., Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Department of Chemical Engineering, Center for Nonlinear Dynamics of Chemical and Biological Systems, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague 6, Czech Republic; Schreiber, I., Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Department of Chemical Engineering, Center for Nonlinear Dynamics of Chemical and Biological Systems, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague 6, Czech Republic; Kubíček, M., Institute of Chemical Technology, Prague, Department of Chemical Engineering, Center for Nonlinear Dynamics of Chemical and Biological Systems, Technická 5, 166 28 Prague 6, Czech Republic
Abstract: Dynamical behavior of reaction-transport processes in a three-way catalyst, where catalytic oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons simultaneously with reduction of NO x occurs, can be in the simplest approximation described by a model of an isothermal stirred flow-through reactor where transport phenomena are neglected but detailed kinetics involving adsorption and chemical steps are considered. Then, the stoichiometric networks analysis can to determine whether there exist kinetically driven dynamical instabilities and what part of the mechanism is responsible for nonlinear phenomena, e.g., multiple steady states and oscillations. The stoichiometric networks approach provides a natural way of decomposing the entire network into subsystems. All potentially unstable subnetworks are systematically examined to reveal the topological differences between the instabilities and those that are likely to be the experimentally observed. The major subnetworks are combined to form the whole mechanism and the resulting spatiotemporal patterns in the corresponding reaction-transport system are compared to those for the subnetworks. This approach leads to a refined classification of complex spatiotemporal dynamics based on that for subsystems possessing only reaction subnetworks showing a specific type of chemical instability. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 18th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering (Prague, Czech Republic 8/24-28/2008).

Authors: Uibu M., Velts O., Trikkel A., Kuusik R.
Title: Reduction of CO2emissions by carbonation of alkaline wastewater
Source title: WIT Transactions on Ecology and the Environment
Affiliations: Laboratory of Inorganic Materials, Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Uibu, M., Laboratory of Inorganic Materials, Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Velts, O., Laboratory of Inorganic Materials, Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Trikkel, A., Laboratory of Inorganic Materials, Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia; Kuusik, R., Laboratory of Inorganic Materials, Tallinn University of Technology, Estonia
Abstract: In energy production based on combustion of fossil fuels, particularly the low-grade ones (lignite, sulphur-rich coal, oil shale etc.), huge amounts of alkaline wastewater are formed. This situation is characteristic for the Republic of Estonia where 59 of the need in primary energy was covered by local oil shale in 2006. Due to the calcareous origin of the mineral part of oil shale, its combustion yields lime-containing ashes (5-6 million tons annually, containing 10-25 of lime as free CaO) as well as enhanced amounts of CO 2(up to 29.1 t C per TJ energy produced) as compared to coal combustion. To transport the ash into wet open-air deposits, a hydraulic system is used. As a result tens of millions of cubic meters of alkaline water (pH level 12-13) saturated by Ca2+- ions is recycling between the plant and sedimentation ponds. Before directing excessive water to nature it should be neutralized to a pH level accepted by environmental regulations ( 9). Related to this, the current work was targeted to develop possibilities for neutralizing wastewater with CO2-containing flue gases, leading to reduction of CO2 emissions. Intensification of respective heterogeneous gas-liquid reactions and characterization of calcium carbonate (PCC) forming were other objectives of the study. A cycle of laboratory-scale neutralization experiments using industrial wastewater samples and a model gas of flue gas composition has been carried out. Two different reactors - barboter-type columns and a dispergator-type phase mixer - have been comparatively examined. Sedimentation of PCC particles of rhombohedral crystallic structure has been shown and their main characteristics have been determined. A neutralization method having up to fifty times higher specific intensity has been proposed. According to calculations 970-1010 tons of CO2 can be trapped and 2200-2300 tons of PCC per million cubic meters of water can be obtained.
Author Keywords: Alkaline wastewater; Ca-compounds; Carbon dioxide; Carbonation; Precipitated calcium carbonate
Index Keywords: alkaline water; atmospheric chemistry; calcium carbonate; carbon dioxide; combustion; environmental legislation; fossil fuel; pH; recycling; reduction; sedimentation; wastewater

Authors: Uliasz-Misiak B.
Title: Risk of co2 geological storage [ryzyko związane z geologicznym składowaniem co2]
Affiliations: Instytut Gospodarki Surowcami Mineralnymi i Energia PAN, Kraków, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Uliasz-Misiak, B., Instytut Gospodarki Surowcami Mineralnymi i Energia PAN, Kraków, Poland
Abstract: Geological storage of CO2 is carried out in three stages: capture, transport and injection and its storage. The human and environmental threats result from large, uncontrolled amounts of carbon dioxide reaching the atmosphere. CO2 transport risk (f. ex.: pipelines) and thronging (surface and deep-seated equipment of boreholes) is well recognized and may be minimized by the use of suitable technologies decreasing the possibility of failure. The process of carbon dioxide storage is complex and that is why the evaluation of probability of involved threats occurrence and their scale estimation is difficult and dependent on many factors, such as the trapping mechanisms, boreholes quality and cohesion of overburden rocks. Drills, faults and fractures are the main paths where CO2 escape from storage site may occur. Risk minimizing is implemented through monitoring carried out while storage and after its completion. The risk connected with geological storage of CO2 is the key issue influencing the social approval of this technology and legal regulations as well as technological standards applied in industrial storage of carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide in large concentrations can influence people, animals and ecosystem. Negative environmental effects caused by effluent of stored CO2 may be considered in the global and local scale. Gas migrating from the structure in which it is stored towards the surface can cause change of quality of superficial and underground waters, soils and changes surface and subsurface ecosystems. If carbon dioxide will get to level of drinking waters, then even its small quantities can change of chemism and deterioration of quality of these waters. Dissolved CO2 creates carbon acid, changing pH of water and causing sequence of indirect effects such as: mobility of toxic metals, chlorides and sulfides. Increased concentration of CO2 in soil will cause decrease of its pH, will influence negatively chemism of nutritious substances and will cause mobility of trace metals (IPCC, 2005). Stored CO2 can influence plants and animals. Its influence on microorganisms living deep in the ground and on plants and animals living in shallow layers of the ground is anticipated. Influence of increased CO2 concentration on microorganisms is subject of many investigations at present. Results show that there is a group of microorganisms which develop well at increased concentration of carbon dioxide [12].

Authors: Uline C., Tschannen-Moran M.
Title: The walls speak: The interplay of quality facilities, school climate, and student achievement
Affiliations: San Diego State University, San Diego, CA, United States; College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Uline, C., San Diego State University, San Diego, CA, United States; Tschannen-Moran, M., College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, VA, United States
Abstract: Purpose - A growing body of research connecting the quality of school facilities to student performance accompanies recent efforts to improve the state of the educational infrastructure in the USA. Less is known about the mechanisms of these relationships. This paper seeks to examine the proposition that part of the explanation may be the mediating influence of school climate. Design/methodology/approach - Teachers from 80 Virginia middle schools were surveyed employing measures including the School Climate Index, a seven-item quality of school facilities scale, as well as three resource support items. Data on student SES and achievement were also gathered. Bivariate correlational analysis was used to explore the relationships between the quality of facilities, resource support, school climate, student SES, and student achievement. In addition, multiple regression was used to test school climate as a mediating variable between the quality of facilities and student achievement. Findings - Results confirmed a link between the quality of school facilities and student achievement in English and mathematics. As well, quality facilities were significantly positively related to three school climate variables. Finally, results confirmed the hypothesis that school climate plays a mediating role in the relationship between facility quality and student achievement. Originality/value - As we face fundamental issues of equity across schools and districts, leaders struggle to convince taxpayers of the need to invest in replacing and/or renovating inadequate facilities. Deeper understandings of the complicated interplay between the physical and social environments of school, and how these dynamics influence student outcomes, may help educators build a compelling case. © Emerald Group Publishing Limited.
Author Keywords: Facilities; Quality; School buildings; Schools; Students; United States of America

Authors: Unn E., Tarasov A., Paretsky V.
Title: Design and engineering of the plant for man-made hydrocarbon-containing raw materials available in countries of the Baltic Sea Region
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 Global Symposium on Recycling, Waste Treatment and Clean Technology, REWAS 2008

Korolyov Street, Moscow, 129515, Russian Federation
Abstract: The stability of the markets of energy resources and labor in countries of the Baltic Sea Region including Estonia is determined to a significant degree by the use of combustible shales as fuel and their distillation resulting in generation of up to 70% of non-recyclable waste. The objective of this business plan is to substantiate the investments for establishment of a new facility in Estonia for waste-less and environmentally safe processing of fossil minerals and man-made products generated in the shale industry, as well as other hazardous wastes. The proposed facility will use a basically new waste processing technology developed in Russia - i.e., processing in sparged molten slag This technology eliminates any release of harmful pollutants to the environment and a facility using this technology does not require, therefore, any sanitary protection zone.

Authors: Unrau G.D., Jain R., Singh R.B., Fournier J.L.
Title: Assessment of mobile emissions in the Athabasca oil sands region - CALPUFF modelling case study using high resolution emission estimates
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Golder Associates Ltd., 1000, 940-6th Avenue S.W., Calgary, Alta. T2P 3T1, Canada; Golder Associates Ltd., 2390 Argentia Road, Mississauga, Ont. L5N 5Z7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Unrau, G.D., Golder Associates Ltd., 1000, 940-6th Avenue S.W., Calgary, Alta. T2P 3T1, Canada; Jain, R., Golder Associates Ltd., 1000, 940-6th Avenue S.W., Calgary, Alta. T2P 3T1, Canada; Singh, R.B., Golder Associates Ltd., 2390 Argentia Road, Mississauga, Ont. L5N 5Z7, Canada; Fournier, J.L., Golder Associates Ltd., 1000, 940-6th Avenue S.W., Calgary, Alta. T2P 3T1, Canada
Abstract: The Golder Associates Mining Emission (GAME) model was used to develop emission profiles for a generic oil sands mine fleet. The CALPUFF dispersion model was used to estimate acid deposition and ground-level NOx and SO2 concentrations. The CALPUFF model was run in the dynamic (three-dimensional) mode using wind fields developed using the CALMET model. Modeling results were compared with those obtained using more traditional emission estimate tools. Modeling showed that the refined GAME model resulted in reduced NOx emissions and consequently reduced predictions of both Potential Acid Input (PAI) and NO2. Reductions in PAI occurred despite an increase in SO2 emissions. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 101st AWMA Annual Conference and Exhibition (Portland, OR 6/24-27/2008).
Author Keywords: CALPUFF; Emission factors; Mine fleet emissions; Oxides of nitrogen; PAI

Authors: Uppala S., Simmons A., Dee D., Kållberg P., Thépaut J.-N.
Title: Atmospheric reanalyses and climate variations
Affiliations: European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts, United Kingdom; The Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Uppala, S., European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts, United Kingdom; Simmons, A., European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts, United Kingdom; Dee, D., European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts, United Kingdom; Kållberg, P., The Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute, Sweden; Thépaut, J.-N., European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Earth’s climate has traditionally been studied by statistical analysis of observations of particular weather elements such as temperature, wind and rainfall. Climatological information, usually expressed as long-term averages and variability, is then presented over a geographical area or at a single location and time series of these quantities or of the observations themselves are examined for evidence of warming, more-frequent severe storms, and so on. A powerful new approach to climate analysis has emerged in recent years. It applies the tools and techniques of modern everyday weather forecasting in a process called reanalysis. The products, reanalyses, have applicability far beyond that of traditional climate information. Reanalyses have become established as an important and widely utilized resource for the study of atmospheric and oceanic processes and predictability also over the data sparse polar regions. They are used in a range of applications that require a comprehensive record of the state of either the atmosphere or its underlying land and ocean surfaces. The reanalysis products, unlike their operational counterparts, do not suffer from inhomogeneities introduced by changes in the data assimilation system. Thus they are in principle better suited for use in studies of low frequency variability and climate trends that complement studies of climate change based on individual instrumental records and climate-model simulations. Climate quality requirements can be met by reanalyses for the decades with good upper-air data coverage by satellites or at least radiosonde data. The possibility of extending reanalyses to cover earlier periods when only surface observations are available in reasonable numbers (e.g., from the 1850s to the 1930s) is nevertheless of interest, and has been explored in pilot studies comparing analyses with good coverage of satellite and other upper-air data with analyses using only surface-pressure observations. © Springer Science + Business Media B.V. 2008.
Author Keywords: Data assimilation; Data assimilation system; Reanalysis product; Satellite radiance; Southern hemisphere

Authors: Utley B., Ludwig A., Cundiff J., McGinnis S.
Title: Organization of an introductory green engineering course for engineering undergraduates
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference and Exposition, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Authors with affiliations: Utley, B., Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University; Ludwig, A., Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University; Cundiff, J., Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University; McGinnis, S., Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Abstract: An "Introduction to Green Engineering" course is one of two core courses required for a Green Engineering minor. Since the course attracts students from all disciplines within the College of Engineering, it is challenging to teach given the variety of backgrounds, specific skills and knowledge, and perspectives. Analysis of course assessment data and revision to the course content and teaching methods are part of an on-going effort to improve this course. The Green Engineering course has lectures which present background material on the key environmental and energy issues facing society. To differentiate this course from one in environmental science, an engineering analysis component is included with the assignment of four mini-projects which are completed by teams of not more than four students. The projects are: 1) biomass logistics, a project to document the increase in per-Mg feedstock hauling cost as plant capacity increases; 2) climate, a project to calculate per capita carbon release for Virginia Tech students, Blacksburg residents, and Montgomery County residents; 3) wetland design, a project to design a constructed wetland facility for the treatment of small municipality wastewater; and 4) biomaterials, an optimization problem to design a structural component using an optimum mix of recycled plastic and organic fiber. © American Society for Engineering Education, 2008.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Curricula; Education; Engineering education; Optimization; Students; Technical presentations; Wastewater treatment; Wetlands; Constructed wetlands; Engineering analysis; Engineering undergraduates; Environmental science; Green engineering; Optimization problems; Recycled plastics; Structural component; Teaching

Authors: Uzarowski L., Moore G.
Title: Sustainable pavements - Making the case for longer design lives for flexible pavements
Source title: TAC/ATC 2008 - 2008 Annual Conference and Exhibition of the Transportation Association of Canada: Transportation - A Key to a Sustainable Future
Affiliations: Golder Ltd., Whitby, ON, Canada; Engineering Services, Capital Planning and Implementation, Public Works Department, Hamilton, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Uzarowski, L., Golder Ltd., Whitby, ON, Canada; Moore, G., Engineering Services, Capital Planning and Implementation, Public Works Department, Hamilton, ON, Canada
Abstract: Over one quarter of the world's greenhouse gas emissions are caused by transportation and especially road transportation. It is critical for the road construction industry to become part of the solution by proactively implementing technology and construction practices that assist in achieving these challenging emission reduction goals. In addition to improved asphalt technology, better construction and rehabilitation methods, and optimized pavement selection based on life-cycle cost analysis, more attention needs to be focused on pavement sustainability. This concept can be defined as a safe, efficient and environmentally friendly pavement that meets the needs of present-day users without compromising those of future generations. This paper will consider some aspects of perpetual pavement sustainability based on a practical application of the concept on the Red Hill Valley Parkway project in the City of Hamilton, Ontario. Essentially by designing and building low maintenance highways that have extended serviceable lives, there are environmental benefits in terms of reduced impact on the environment and reduced cumulative greenhouse gas emissions. The assessment of the overall impacts of construction on the environment during road building and maintenance operations used in this paper are based on European experience, particularly in France. In addition, the Pavement Life-cycle Assessment Tool for Environmental and Economic Effects (PaLATE) computer program developed at the University of California, Berkeley was used to calculate the energy consumption and gas emission during initial construction and the pavement maintenance and rehabilitation. The analysis shows that besides the lower life-cycle cost of the perpetual pavement alternative, the environmental impact of this type of pavement is significantly lower than that of the conventional deep strength pavement.
Index Keywords: Construction industry; Cost benefit analysis; Emission control; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; Life cycle; Maintenance; Road construction; Sustainable development; Impact on the environment; Life-cycle assessment tools; Life-cycle cost analysis; Maintenance operations; Pavement maintenance and rehabilitations; Pavement sustainability; Rehabilitation methods; University of California , Berkeley; Pavements

Authors: Uzelac S., Hranilović Trubić A., Šustić I., Würth D.
Title: The influence of high slag dosages in cement on frost and de-icing salt resistance of concrete
Source title: Proceedings of the International FIB Symposium 2008 - Tailor Made Concrete Structures: New Solutions for our Society
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Institute of Croatia, Zagreb, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Uzelac, S., Civil Engineering Institute of Croatia, Zagreb, Croatia; Hranilović Trubić, A., Civil Engineering Institute of Croatia, Zagreb, Croatia; Šustić, I., Civil Engineering Institute of Croatia, Zagreb, Croatia; Würth, D., Civil Engineering Institute of Croatia, Zagreb, Croatia
Abstract: New types of concrete („green” concrete, high and ultra high strength concrete) has developed recently. In meantime awareness of the need for reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the construction industry bas resulted in increasingly environmentally friendly cement production. It is known if the clinker part in cement is substituted with mineral additives (slag from a blast fumace, fly ash), the CO2 ernission is significantly reduced. The serviceability of a such cement type should be tested in local conditions with the aim of preserving effects of the environmentally friendly production. © 2008 Taylor & Francis Group, London.

Authors: Valente A.
Title: Installation for pressure reduction of hydrocarbon gases in a near isothermal manner
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - 13th Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference, ADIPEC 2008
Affiliations: Partex Services Portugal, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Valente, A., Partex Services Portugal, Portugal
Abstract: New equipment designed for achieving the pressure reduction of Hydrocarbon gases in a near isothermal manner with the simultaneous recovery of its elastic energy lost during pressure reduction thermodynamic process. The equipment is consisting on utilizing a Tesla turbine which rotor is composed of several parallel plane discs rotating by boundary layer effect, induced by the moving gas drag when spirally passing parallel to those discs, associated with an electrical power generator. During experimental tests it was found that the gas to be processed suffers a pressure reduction, by loss of energy transmitted to the rotor, in a near isothermal manner contrary to the usual equipments utilized in the actual state of the art. Taking advantage of the said discovered singularity the equipment will be applied for pressure reduction of Hydrocarbon gases, without the temperature reduction associated if utilizing the Joule-Thomson effect and in addition will generate energy. It will also be applied in Hydrocarbon gas liquefaction, with in a first step of near isothermal pressure reduction complemented by a cryogenic stage of liquefaction where the energy required will be derived from one generated on the first step. In the actual energetic conjuncture, this equipment will provide a pressure reduction thermodynamic process for gas pressure reduction stations in gas transmission pipelines that does not require the supply of external energy for re heating, with the associated cost and pollution and on top of it, recovers in the form of electrical energy part of the elastic energy lost by the gas. It is also significant the application of this equipment in gas liquefaction plants, since it will achieve the desired results with lesser energy consumption. Copyright 2008, Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Associated costs; Boundary layer effects; Elastic energy; Electrical energy; Electrical power generators; Energy consumption; Experimental test; External energy; Gas liquefaction; Gas pressures; Gas transmission pipeline; Hydro-carbon gas; Joule-Thomson effect; Loss of energy; Parallel planes; Pressure reduction; State of the art; Temperature reduction; Thermodynamic process; Equipment; Gas plants; Gases; Hydrocarbons; Liquefaction of gases; Natural gas transportation; Pressure effects; Thermodynamics; Thermoelectricity; Electric generators

Authors: Valenzuela O.R., Gallardo C.S., Kämpf A.N.
Title: Regional components used as growing media in argentina
Affiliations: Facultad de Ciencias Agropecuarias, Universidad Nacional de Entre Rios, Paraná, Entre Ríos, Argentina; CNPq-Researcher, Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Valenzuela, O.R., Facultad de Ciencias Agropecuarias, Universidad Nacional de Entre Rios, Paraná, Entre Ríos, Argentina; Gallardo, C.S., Facultad de Ciencias Agropecuarias, Universidad Nacional de Entre Rios, Paraná, Entre Ríos, Argentina; Kämpf, A.N., CNPq-Researcher, Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil
Abstract: This study describes samples of 57 materials commonly used for seedling production in Argentina, with the objective to reduce the lack of literature on plant substrates in this country. The organic samples include two types of subtropical peat, pine bark at different grades of decomposition, vermicompost of diverse origins and carbonized rice hulls; the inorganic samples include: mineral soil, sand and others. The following characteristics were determined in three repetitions: total porosity (TP), dry bulk density (Ds), particle density (Dp); water retention capacity (WRC) at 10 hPa, air-filled porosity (AP), pH-value (pH) and salinity (EC). The peat from Delta de Entre Rios is fibrous with pieces of grass and ferns still present, has a high value of TP (between 84 and 93% v/v) and 42%v of WRC. The peat from Concordia is more mineralized, dark colored, with high WRC (61 %v), low pH (from 3.5 to 5.3) and EC value from 0.03 to 3 dS/m (25°C). Pine bark presents TP > 85%v with WRC varying between 30 and 49% v/v and pH from 3.5 to 5.6. Vermicompost is a very heterogeneous material, intensively used by small growers. The variability among the results was very significant (p < 0.001). The samples showed values of TP varying from 73 to 92%v and WRC between 20 and 66% v/v. Despite already in use as a component for plant substrates in Brazil, carbonized rice hulls remain almost unknown in Argentina, where its potential use should be studied, due to the local rice crop production. The very low WRC (ca. 20% v/v) of this material can be limiting for some uses. To conclude, this study opens a new line of investigation on qualified plant substrates to replace the present use of mineral soils and sand materials.
Author Keywords: Organic and inorganic components; Physical and chemical properties; Plant substrates; South America
Index Keywords: Filicophyta

Authors: Vallabhajosyula P., Bourell D.L.
Title: Selective laser sintering and post processing of fully ferrous components
Source title: 19th Annual International Solid Freeform Fabrication Symposium, SFF 2008
Affiliations: Laboratory of Freeform Fabrication, Advanced Manufacturing Center, University of Texas at Austin, 1University Station, Austin, TX 78712-0292, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vallabhajosyula, P., Laboratory of Freeform Fabrication, Advanced Manufacturing Center, University of Texas at Austin, 1University Station, Austin, TX 78712-0292, United States; Bourell, D.L., Laboratory of Freeform Fabrication, Advanced Manufacturing Center, University of Texas at Austin, 1University Station, Austin, TX 78712-0292, United States
Abstract: Commercially available steel for indirect SLS (LaserFormtm A6 tool steel) is normally post-process infiltrated with a copper-based material. While such parts have high thermal conductivity necessary for short- and medium-run injection molding dies, they are weakened by the second phase with limited high temperature stability. This paper deals with a modification to the commercial process whereby a low-melting-point cast iron is substituted for the copper alloy infiltrant. A predictive model is presented that describes the part equilibrium solid fraction at the infiltration temperature as a function of the green density and infiltration temperature. In an experimental study, green parts were fabricated using LaserFormtm A6 tool steel powder. They were then heated in vacuum to drive off the binder and infiltrated with ASTM A532 white cast iron. During infiltration, an equilibrium state is established between the solid SLS steel part and liquid cast iron associated primarily with carbon diffusion from the cast iron into the tool steel. The equilibrium state is governed by the carbon content of the steel and cast iron, the relative density of the steel part prior to infiltration and the infiltration temperature. In some cases guided by Ashby densification maps, pre-sintering of the tool steel green part was performed to increase the initial relative density of the solid metal.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Cast iron; Laser heating; Sintering; Tool steel; Commercial process; Densification maps; Equilibrium state; High temperature stability; High thermal conductivity; Infiltration temperatures; Predictive modeling; Selective laser sintering; Thermal conductivity

Authors: Van Berlo M.A.J., De Waart H.
Title: Unleashing the power in waste : Comparison of greenhouse gas and other performance indicators for waste-to-energy concepts and landfilling
Source title: 2008 Proceedings of the 16th Annual North American Waste to Energy Conference, NAWTEC16
Affiliations: Afval Energie Bedrij, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Berlo, M.A.J., Afval Energie Bedrij, Amsterdam, Netherlands; De Waart, H., Afval Energie Bedrij, Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: A CO2-e valuation is made for landfill and Waste-to-Energy (WtE) concepts. Different concepts are identified and compared for their performance on energy and materials recovery. Performance indicators for WtE are compared; like energy efficiency, Energy efficiency, the R1-D1O formula from the EU Waste Framework directive, and CO2-emission and avoidance. It is shown that, due to the biomass content and the avoidance effect due to the recovery of energy and materials, conventional WtE has a near zero CO2-emission per ton of waste. Optimised WtE can have a significant negative overall emission of 200-300 kgCO2/ton of waste. This means an absolute net avoidance of CO2 by WtE. The reduction relative to land filling is as much as 500-1200 kgCO2/ton of waste. The potential for optimisation of the energy recovety as well as the material recovety of the WtE infrastructure is demonstrated. If WtE is evaluated as a power plant, an optimised plant can have an emission of only 0,336 kgCO2/kWh, lower than a gas fired electrical power plant, and this absolute figure does not include the avoided landfill emissions. With CHP this can be reduced even further. The actual potential of electricity production from WtE for the EU-15 is calculated to be over 7,5% of total electricity production. Additionally heat and the metal recoveries could be doubled. Copyright © 2008 by ASME.
Author Keywords: CO2-avoidence; CO2-evaluation; Energy efficiency; Exergy; Greenhouse gas; Landfill; Municipal solid waste; Recovery; Recycling; Waste-to-energy

Authors: Van Dao L., Teichmann S., Davis J., Hannaford P.
Title: Generation of high flux, highly coherent extreme ultraviolet radiation in a gas cell
Affiliations: ARC Centre of Excellence for Coherent X-Ray Science, Centre for Atom Optics and Ultrafast Spectroscopy, Swinburne University of Technology, Melbourne, VIC 3122, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Van Dao, L., ARC Centre of Excellence for Coherent X-Ray Science, Centre for Atom Optics and Ultrafast Spectroscopy, Swinburne University of Technology, Melbourne, VIC 3122, Australia; Teichmann, S., ARC Centre of Excellence for Coherent X-Ray Science, Centre for Atom Optics and Ultrafast Spectroscopy, Swinburne University of Technology, Melbourne, VIC 3122, Australia; Davis, J., ARC Centre of Excellence for Coherent X-Ray Science, Centre for Atom Optics and Ultrafast Spectroscopy, Swinburne University of Technology, Melbourne, VIC 3122, Australia; Hannaford, P., ARC Centre of Excellence for Coherent X-Ray Science, Centre for Atom Optics and Ultrafast Spectroscopy, Swinburne University of Technology, Melbourne, VIC 3122, Australia
Abstract: We report the generation of extreme ultraviolet radiation with high photon flux (1010-1012 photon/cm2 s), high spatial coherence (up to 0.95), and good spatial beam profile by high-order harmonic generation in various noble gases (argon, neon, and helium) in a gas cell. The photon flux was determined using an extreme ultraviolet spectrometer equipped with a charge-coupled device camera and the spatial coherence was determined from Young double-slit interference fringes. The high-order harmonic emission is confined to just a few orders because of the small phase mismatch in the cut-off region that allows macroscopic phase matching to be satisfied for just a few harmonics in this region. The efficiency and spatial beam profile are studied as a function of gas pressure and geometrical configuration. © 2008 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Laser pulses; Solar radiation; Ultraviolet devices; Extreme ultraviolet radiation; Gas cells; High flux; Photon fluxes; Ultraviolet radiation

Authors: Van De Beek J., Berggren F.
Title: Out-of-band power suppression in OFDM
Affiliations: Huawei Technologies Sweden, P.O. Box 54, SE-164 94 Kista, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Van De Beek, J., Huawei Technologies Sweden, P.O. Box 54, SE-164 94 Kista, Sweden; Berggren, F., Huawei Technologies Sweden, P.O. Box 54, SE-164 94 Kista, Sweden
Abstract: In this letter we show that judicious modulation of non-data subcarriers renders a transmitted OFDM signal and a few of its higher-order derivatives continuous at the OFDM symbol boundaries. This novel approach results in reduced out-of-band emission: typically, it achieves over 30 dB power suppression at adjacent-channel center-frequencies. © 2008 IEEE.

Authors: Van Der Brugge R., De Graaf R.
Title: Transforming water infrastructure by linking water management and urban renewal in Rotterdam
Source title: 2008 1st International Conference on Infrastructure Systems and Services: Building Networks for a Brighter Future, INFRA 2008
Affiliations: Erasmus University Rotterdam, Drift, Faculty of Social Sciences, PO Box 1738, Rotterdam, Netherlands; Delft University of Technology, Section of Water Resources, PO Box 5048, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Der Brugge, R., Erasmus University Rotterdam, Drift, Faculty of Social Sciences, PO Box 1738, Rotterdam, Netherlands; De Graaf, R., Delft University of Technology, Section of Water Resources, PO Box 5048, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: There are different viewpoints possible with regard to new urban water infrastructural investments. A relatively new point of view is that renewal of water infrastructure needs to be linked to ongoing urban developments and urban renewal projects. This article investigates how water management in the city of Rotterdam developed its climate adaptation strategy by creating water management strategies linked to urban development strategies. A crucial factor for this new viewpoint was the recognition that water could contribute to solve urban problems by upgrading deprived neighbourhoods. This research indicates that the urban water managers in Rotterdam have initiated a successful water policy innovation, however, the institutional mechanisms in order to realize and maintain the proposed multistakeholder projects are still lacking. This is currently the major challenge for realizing climate adaptation in terms of water sensitive urban development.
Index Keywords: Adaptation strategies; Multi-stakeholder; Rotterdam; Urban development; Urban renewal; Urban waters; Water infrastructure; Water policies; Water sensitive; Strategic planning; Water management; Water supply; Investments

Authors: Van Groenigen J.W., Schils R.L.M., Velthof G.L., Kuikman P.J., Oudendag D.A., Oenema O.
Title: Mitigation strategies for greenhouse gas emissions from animal production systems: Synergy between measuring and modelling at different scales
Affiliations: Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands; Department of Soil Quality, Wageningen University, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Groenigen, J.W., Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands, Department of Soil Quality, Wageningen University, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands; Schils, R.L.M., Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands; Velthof, G.L., Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands; Kuikman, P.J., Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands; Oudendag, D.A., Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands; Oenema, O., Alterra, Wageningen University and Research Centre, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands, Department of Soil Quality, Wageningen University, PO Box 47, 6700 AA, Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: Animal production systems are large and complex sources of greenhouse gases (GHG), especially nitrous oxide (N2O) and methane (CH4). Emissions from these systems are expected to rise over the coming decades due to the increasing global population and shifting diets, unless appropriate mitigation strategies are implemented. In this paper, we argue that the main constraints for such implementation are: (i) the complex and often poorly understood controls of GHG sources in animal production systems; (ii) the lack of knowledge on the economic and social costs involved in implementing mitigation strategies; and (iii) the strong political emphasis on mitigating nitrate leaching and ammonia volatilisation, rather than GHG emissions. We further argue that overcoming these three constraints can only be achieved by initiating integrated mitigation strategies, based on modelling and experimental work at three scales. At the 'laboratory and field scale', basic causal relationships with respect to processes of GHG formation and other detrimental fluxes need to be experimentally established and modelled. As management options are considered at the 'farm scale', this is the ideal scale to evaluate the cost-effectiveness, feasibility and possible pollution swapping effects of mitigation measures. Finally, at the 'national and supra-national scales', environmental legislation is implemented, effectiveness of environmental policies and emissions abatement measures are being monitored, and the social costs of various scenarios are being weighed. We illustrate the need for integral measures and working across different scales using our own work on the relationship between nitrogen surplus and fluxes to the environment. At the field scale, a clear positive relation between nitrogen surplus and N 2O emission, NO3- leaching and NH3 volatilisation was experimentally established. At the farm scale, the model DAIRYWISE was used to evaluate effects of minimising nitrogen surplus on the nutrient flow and economic viability of an average Dutch dairy farm. Even after including trade-off effects of CH4 emissions from cattle and manure storage, there was still a clear positive relationship between farm gate nitrogen surplus and GHG emission. At this scale, the prime issue was balancing environmental gains with economic viability. Finally, at the 'national and supra-national scale' we developed the MITERRA-EUROPE model, and used it to quantify the effects on GHG emissions of environmental policies aimed at reducing NO3- leaching and NH3 volatilisation in the 27 Member States of the European Union (EU-27). This showed the intricate relationship between different environmental goals, with both positive feedback (balanced fertilisation reduced both NO3- leaching and N2O emission) and negative feedback ('low-emission' manure application reduced NH3 volatilisation but increased N2O emission) possible. At this scale, there is a clear need for an integral approach towards reducing environmental assessment to the environment. Our studies so far suggest that 'balanced fertilisation' is among the most promising mitigation measures for simultaneously lowering N2O emission, NO3- leaching and NH3 volatilisation, without pollution swapping to CH4 emission. © CSIRO 2008.
Author Keywords: Ammonia volatilisation; Methane; Nitrate leaching; Nitrous oxide
Index Keywords: abatement cost; ammonia; environmental legislation; environmental policy; experimental study; greenhouse gas; implementation process; methane; mitigation; nitrous oxide; strategic approach; volatilization; Animalia; Bos

Authors: van Oosterzee P., Garnett S.T.
Title: Seeing REDD: Issues, principles and possible opportunities in Northern Australia
Affiliations: BIOCARBON, P.O. Box 1200, Atherton, QLD 4883, Australia; School for Environmental Research, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, NT 0909, Australia
Authors with affiliations: van Oosterzee, P., BIOCARBON, P.O. Box 1200, Atherton, QLD 4883, Australia; Garnett, S.T., School for Environmental Research, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, NT 0909, Australia
Abstract: When the Kyoto Protocol was drafted, a major opportunity was lost to conserve existing stands of rainforest, particularly in developing countries, through the recognition of the benefits of reduced emissions from deforestation and degradation (known as REDD). Even post-Kyoto, arguments persist for excluding REDD and related schemes from carbon accounting systems. The gap in mandated procedures, however, has to some extent been filled by the voluntary market which draws investment from companies wishing to demonstrate their environmental credentials to investors. This innovative market has products that extend beyond carbon to biodiversity and social benefits. The issues and principles involved are addressed in this article, along with reference to two possible REDD opportunities in northern Australia. Sadly, one of these opportunities has just been missed. For the other, institutional mechanisms will be needed to allow owners of intact forests to benefit from their carbon value and related environmental services potential. Copyright © 2008 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Authors: Van 't Ooster A., Heuvelink E., Loaiza Mejía V.M., Van Henten E.J.
Title: Technical solutions to prevent heat stress induced crop growth reduction for three climatic regions in Mexico
Affiliations: Farm Technology Group, Wageningen University, P.O.Box 17, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands; Horticultural Production Chains, Wageningen University, Marijkeweg 22, 6709 PG Wageningen, Netherlands; Royal Pride Holland, Wagenpad 12, 1775RJ Middenmeer, Netherlands; Wageningen UR Greenhouse Horticulture, P.O.Box 16, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van 't Ooster, A., Farm Technology Group, Wageningen University, P.O.Box 17, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands; Heuvelink, E., Horticultural Production Chains, Wageningen University, Marijkeweg 22, 6709 PG Wageningen, Netherlands; Loaiza Mejía, V.M., Royal Pride Holland, Wagenpad 12, 1775RJ Middenmeer, Netherlands; Van Henten, E.J., Farm Technology Group, Wageningen University, P.O.Box 17, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands, Wageningen UR Greenhouse Horticulture, P.O.Box 16, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: In the last 15 years a significant increase in greenhouse area has occurred in Mexico, from a modest 50 hectares in 1990 to over 2,000 hectares in 2004. The rapid increase in greenhouse area is a result of an attractive export market, USA. Mexican summer midday temperatures are well above crop optimum and cooling is needed if heat stress induced crop growth reduction is to be prevented. The objective of this study was to determine the effectiveness and feasibility of greenhouse cooling systems for tomato culture under desert, humid tropic and temperate Mexican weather conditions. These climate regions are represented by Mexicali, Merida and Huejutla respectively. The cooling systems included a variety of passive and active systems, which through an engineering design methodology were combined to suit the climate conditions of the 3 regions. The evaluation was conducted via simulation, taking into account the most important temperature effects on crop growth and yield. The results showed that the cooling systems were effective in decreasing heat stress to plants. Investment costs of greenhouse with cooling equipment were under USD 50 m -2 and operational costs were under USD 10 m-2 for all equipment combinations and treatments except for the humid tropic climate of Merida. Solutions for Merida were both economically and physically not feasible due to too high humidity levels. This model study clearly indicates that cooling is feasible in desert and moderate climate regions of Mexico but in humid tropic climate regions feasibility is a problem. Application of design methodology and design evaluation with help of simulation greatly contributed to pointing out effective and non-effective solutions to reduce heat stress in hot climates.
Author Keywords: Greenhouse climate; Greenhouse technology; Model; Resource use; Tomato
Index Keywords: Lycopersicon esculentum

Authors: Van T.T., Bao H.D.X.
Title: Application of Geoinformatics to urban environmental management in view of urban climatology: Case study in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
Source title: 29th Asian Conference on Remote Sensing 2008, ACRS 2008
Affiliations: Institute for Environment and Resources, Vietnam National University Ho Chi Minh City, 142 To Hien Thanh Rd. Dist. 10, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Environmental Science Faculty, Sai Gon University, 273 An Duong Vuong St. Dist. 5, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Van, T.T., Institute for Environment and Resources, Vietnam National University Ho Chi Minh City, 142 To Hien Thanh Rd. Dist. 10, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bao, H.D.X., Environmental Science Faculty, Sai Gon University, 273 An Duong Vuong St. Dist. 5, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Rapid urbanization and industrialization have resulted in sharp land cover changes. Urban change not only impacts on land cover but also on urban climate. Land surface and atmospheric modifications due to urbanization generally lead to a modified thermal climate that is warmer than the surrounding non-urbanized areas. In this research Geoinformatics technology were utilized to evaluate urban growth patterns and its thermal characteristics through mapping impervious surfaces and evaluating thermal infrared images. The study case is northern part of Ho Chi Minh City, where urban area is expanded manyfold. Landsat and Aster images were used to calculate variation in urban impervious surfaces from 1989 to 2006. Thermal bands were processed to obtain radiant surface temperatures for investigating the urban heat island effect associated with increasing impervious surfaces both spatially and temporally. Impacts of urban growth on the climate conditions of urban and suburban areas in study area have been investigated by analyzing the change of surface temperature, impervious surface area using data collected from satellite images and historical climate in-situ measurements in the region. The results of this study shows an evidence to application capacity of powerful and potential satellite remote sensing on monitoring urban environment in Vietnam, especially on urban climatology research considering the heat energy processes.

Authors: Vandenburg T.F.
Title: California's "early action measures" to reduce greenhouse gas emissions
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Dongell Lawrence Finney LLP, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vandenburg, T.F., Dongell Lawrence Finney LLP, United States
Abstract: The State of California is currently working aggressively to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the State to 1990 levels by the year 2020. The early action measures include a low carbon fuel standard, restrictions on recharging of refrigeration systems, landfill methane recapture, truck efficiency measures, port electrification, reduction of perfluorocarbons use by the semiconductor industry, reduction of propellants in consumer products, tire inflation measures, and prohibitions on the use of sulfur hexafluoride by certain industries. Regulations concerning these measures are expected to be adopted soon. CARB's staff has recommended adoption of programs, regulations or research initiatives in several areas by 2012, i.e., refrigerant tracking, reporting and recovery; energy efficiency measures for cement facilities; measures to encourage or mandate the use of blending materials in cement; enforcement of truck anti-idling regulations, and research to develop reductions of greenhouse gas emissions from nitrogen land application. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 101st AWMA Annual Conference and Exhibition (Portland, OR 6/24-27/2008).

Authors: Vanderzaag A.C., Gordon R.J., Jamieson R.C., Burton D.L., Stratton G.W.
Title: Straw covers to reduce gas emissions from liquid dairy manure storage
Source title: American Society of Agricultural and Biological Engineers Annual International Meeting 2008, ASABE 2008
Affiliations: Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada; Dept. of Engineering, Nova Scotia Agricultural College, Truro, NS, Canada; Dept. Process Eng. and Applied Sci., Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada; Dept. of Environmental Science, Nova Scotia Agricultural College, Truro, NS, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Vanderzaag, A.C., Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada; Gordon, R.J., Dept. of Engineering, Nova Scotia Agricultural College, Truro, NS, Canada; Jamieson, R.C., Dept. Process Eng. and Applied Sci., Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada; Burton, D.L., Dept. of Environmental Science, Nova Scotia Agricultural College, Truro, NS, Canada; Stratton, G.W., Dept. of Environmental Science, Nova Scotia Agricultural College, Truro, NS, Canada
Abstract: The objective of this study was to investigate the effect of floating straw covers on gas emissions from liquid dairy manure during undisturbed storage and during agitation. Emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), and ammonia (NH2) were measured between June and October 2007 from six tanks (6.6 m2) containing liquid dairy manure in Nova Scotia, Canada. Straw was added to four of the tanks at two thicknesses (15 and 30 cm), while two tanks remained uncovered. Concentrations were measured using tunable diode lasers, an infra-red gas analyzer, and acid traps, while fluxes were measured using steady-state chambers. At the end of the study one tank from each treatment was agitated. During 122 d of undisturbed storage the 15 and 30 cm straw cover treatments both reduced total greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 20% and NH3 emissions by 78 and 90%, respectively. During 5d of agitation, substantial releases of CO2, CH4 and NH3 were observed from all treatments and this decreased the overall reduction of NH3 emissions provided by the 15 and 30 cm straw cover treatments to 68 and 76%, respectively. The results suggest floating straw covers can reduce both GHG and NH3 emissions from liquid dairy manure and that agitation contributes to overall storage losses, especially for NH3.

Authors: Vanotti M.B., Szogi A.A., Vives C.A.
Title: Greenhouse gas emission reduction and environmental quality improvement from implementation of aerobic waste treatment systems in swine farms
Affiliations: United States Department of Agriculture, ARS, Coastal Plains Research Center, 2611 W. Lucas St, Florence, SC 29501, United States; Agrosuper, Agricola SuperLimitada, c.c. 333, Rancagua, Chile
Authors with affiliations: Vanotti, M.B., United States Department of Agriculture, ARS, Coastal Plains Research Center, 2611 W. Lucas St, Florence, SC 29501, United States; Szogi, A.A., United States Department of Agriculture, ARS, Coastal Plains Research Center, 2611 W. Lucas St, Florence, SC 29501, United States; Vives, C.A., Agrosuper, Agricola SuperLimitada, c.c. 333, Rancagua, Chile
Abstract: Trading of greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions is an attractive approach to help producers implement cleaner treatment technologies to replace current anaerobic lagoons. Our objectives were to estimate greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions from implementation of aerobic technology in USA swine farms. Emission reductions were calculated using the approved United Nations framework convention on climate change (UNFCCC) methodology in conjunction with monitoring information collected during full-scale demonstration of the new treatment system in a 4360-head swine operation in North Carolina (USA). Emission sources for the project and baseline manure management system were methane (CH4) emissions from the decomposition of manure under anaerobic conditions and nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions during storage and handling of manure in the manure management system. Emission reductions resulted from the difference between total project and baseline emissions. The project activity included an on-farm wastewater treatment system consisting of liquid-solid separation, treatment of the separated liquid using aerobic biological N removal, chemical disinfection and soluble P removal using lime. The project activity was completed with a centralized facility that used aerobic composting to process the separated solids. Replacement of the lagoon technology with the cleaner aerobic technology reduced GHG emissions 96.9%, from 4972 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2-eq) to 153 tonnes CO2-eq/year. Total net emission reductions by the project activity in the 4360-head finishing operation were 4776.6 tonnes CO2-eq per year or 1.10 tonnes CO2-eq/head per year. The dollar value from implementation of this project in this swine farm was US$19,106/year using current Chicago Climate Exchange trading values of US$4/t CO2. This translates into a direct economic benefit to the producer of US$1.75 per finished pig. Thus, GHG emission reductions and credits can help compensate for the higher installation cost of cleaner aerobic technologies and facilitate producer adoption of environmentally superior technologies to replace current anaerobic lagoons in the USA.

Authors: Vatsky J., Shan J., Larson T., O'Kane P., Wang D.
Title: Field operation of a low NOx burner that attains up to 5:1 turndown
Source title: Air and Waste Management Association - 7th Power Plant Air Pollutant Control 'Mega' Symposium 2008
Affiliations: Advanced Burner Technologies Product Group, Siemens Environmental Systems and Services, 271 Route 202/206 South, Pluckemin, NJ 07979, United States; Tarong Energy Operations, Nanango, QLD, 4615, Australia; Jiangsu Ligang Electric Power Co., Ltd., Ligang Town, Jiangsu, 21444, China
Authors with affiliations: Vatsky, J., Advanced Burner Technologies Product Group, Siemens Environmental Systems and Services, 271 Route 202/206 South, Pluckemin, NJ 07979, United States; Shan, J., Advanced Burner Technologies Product Group, Siemens Environmental Systems and Services, 271 Route 202/206 South, Pluckemin, NJ 07979, United States; Larson, T., Advanced Burner Technologies Product Group, Siemens Environmental Systems and Services, 271 Route 202/206 South, Pluckemin, NJ 07979, United States; O'Kane, P., Tarong Energy Operations, Nanango, QLD, 4615, Australia; Wang, D., Jiangsu Ligang Electric Power Co., Ltd., Ligang Town, Jiangsu, 21444, China
Abstract: Two low NOx system retrofits has been successfully performed at Jiangsu Ligang Electric Power, Ltd Boiler #1&2 in Jiangsu City, China. New overfire air system was installed and the existing burners were upgraded by replacing the OEM scroll fuel injector with Opti-Flow™ elbow fuel injectors with difrusers. The existing dual registers were retained with minor modifications. Testing results show that NOxhas been reduced about 71% to below the 400 mg/Nm3 range; there is no flame impingement on the rear wall with any mill out, the furnace is cleaner than before and superheat tube metal temperatures are now within normal ranges. The excellent flame stability of this burner not only allows the firing of very low volatile (high fuel ratio) coals to achieve minimal NOx and minimal CO/UBC, but also to operate at very low capacities (high turn-down ratios at least 4:1) without utilizing auxiliary fuels for flame stabilization to save the support oil or gas consumption and reduce the cost of power plant operation. This excellent flame well mounted back to the throat can reduce NOx, unburnt carbon in the ash, reduce slagging and corrosion risks to improve the efficiency, availability and reliability of the boiler. At Tarong, a successful demonstration of 5:1 turndown with the complete ABT low NOxburner, including secondary air registers and fuel injectors.

Authors: Velic J., Malvic T., Cvetkovic M., Weisser M., Curi V.
Title: Observations useful for increase of hydrocarbon fields exploitation period within a Croatian part of the Pannonian basin
Source title: 8th International Scientific Conference on Modern Management of Mine Producing, Geology and Environmental Protection, SGEM 2008
Affiliations: Geology and Petroleum Engineering, Department of Geology and Geological Engineering, Croatia; INA-Oil Industry Plc, Field Engineering and Development Department, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Velic, J., Geology and Petroleum Engineering, Department of Geology and Geological Engineering, Croatia; Malvic, T., Geology and Petroleum Engineering, Department of Geology and Geological Engineering, Croatia, INA-Oil Industry Plc, Field Engineering and Development Department, Croatia; Cvetkovic, M., Geology and Petroleum Engineering, Department of Geology and Geological Engineering, Croatia; Weisser, M., INA-Oil Industry Plc, Field Engineering and Development Department, Croatia; Curi, V., INA-Oil Industry Plc, Field Engineering and Development Department, Croatia
Abstract: Approximately 110x106 m3 of oil (100x106 tons) had been recovered from 38 fields in the Croatian part of the Pannonian basin during more than 60 years of exploitation (1941-2003). Based on their cumulative production, number of reservoirs, average porosity and permeability, obtained recovery and depositional characteristics of reservoir rocks, the Croatian hydrocarbon fields may be divided into three groups (oil), or four groups (gas) (Table 1, 2). In the period 1941-1990 the production started in 38 fields, 13 of which before 1959. The peak was reached in 1980-1989 period, when exploitation started in 12 new fields. However, estimations of economic exploitation are optimistic. The longest period is assumed for the 1st group of fields - approx. 55 years, while for 2nd and 3rd group 46 and 36 years of exploitation are expected, respectively. Moreover, in the 1st group the average number of reservoirs is 16 and lithological composition is very favourable, since reservoirs are represented by sandstones of Pannonian and Pontian age. The exception is the Beničanci field with a reservoir in Lower and Middle Miocene breccias. The prognosed exploitation period of gas fields (without fields in the Adriatic off-shore) is between 5 and 23 years. Relatively homogeneous sandstone lithology, including good regional seals like marls, enables increasing of recovery using fluid injection. Also, injection of CO2 is planed in favourable reservoirs (immiscible phases, pressure supported) and two pilot projects are either finished (Šandrovac field in 2001) or planned in near future (Ivanić field in 2008). The water-flooding will probably be dominant secondary method for increasing recovery in the future, especially due to the fact that for the CO2 injection gas transport and careful analysis of fluids interactions in sub-surfaces are necessary. Both approaches can be very easily and successfully applied today due to very good regional tectonic, stratigraphic, depositional and geochemical investigations of the Sava and Drava depressions. It is assumed that over 2-4 times more oil was generated than oil discovered up to now. It means that, at least based on presented statistics, probably some larger fields can be discovered especially in the Drava and Sava depressions.
Author Keywords: Croatia; Exploitation period; Hydrocarbons; Pannonian basin

Authors: Velkov L., Papazyan M.
Title: The role of hydro and pumped storage in Bulgaria
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: NEK EAD, 5 Veslets Street, 1040 Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Velkov, L., NEK EAD, 5 Veslets Street, 1040 Sofia, Bulgaria; Papazyan, M., NEK EAD, 5 Veslets Street, 1040 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: The development and role of hydropower and pumped-storage in Bulgaria is discussed. The largest producer of hydroelectric power is the National Electricity Company of Bulgaria (NEK) which is 100 per cent State owned. NEK is the owner of 29 hydropower and pumped-storage plants, with a total installed capacity of 2563 MW. To increase the hydro output and reduce emissions pollutants and greenhouse gases associated with thermal plants, NEK is implementing plans for the construction of new hydropower schemes as well as the refurbishment of existing hydro and pumped-storage plants. Hydropower development is an integral part of the country's overall energy strategy. Hydropower is an established renewable technology which offers the environmental benefits associated with emerging renewable competitors at a cost-effective price, with dependable supply, and the added benefit of opportunities for continued expansion.
